snippet: Days before an Afghan grand council is scheduled to meet, Afghan officials said both sides had refused to budge on American insistence that United States troops retain the right to enter Afghan homes.
abstract: Senior Afghan officials say that negotiations on future of American military presence in country are at profound impasse, deadlocked over American negotiators' insistence that United States troops retain right to enter private homes.

byline.original: By ROD NORDLAND and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
byline.contributor: Rod Nordland reported from Kabul, Afghanistan, and Matthew Rosenberg from Washington. Jawad Sukhanyar contributed reporting from Kabul.

lead_paragraph: Days before an Afghan grand council is scheduled to meet, Afghan officials said both sides had refused to budge on American insistence that United States troops retain the right to enter Afghan homes.

headline.main: Afghan Talks at Impasse Before Vote, Officials Say
headline.print_headline: Afghan Talks At Impasse Before Vote, Officials Say

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
